6030→## What is a "Composable"? {#what-is-a-composable} 6031→ 6032→In the context of Vue applications, a "composable" is a function that leverages Vue's Composition API to encapsulate and reuse **stateful logic**. 6033→ 6034→When building frontend applications, we often need to reuse logic for common tasks. For example, we may need to format dates in many places, so we extract a reusable function for that. This formatter function encapsulates **stateless logic**: it takes some input and immediately returns expected output. There are many libraries out there for reusing stateless logic - for example [lodash](https://lodash.com/) and [date-fns](https://date-fns.org/), which you may have heard of. 6035→ 6036→By contrast, stateful logic involves managing state that changes over time. A simple example would be tracking the current position of the mouse on a page. In real-world scenarios, it could also be more complex logic such as touch gestures or connection status to a database. 6037→ 6038→## Mouse Tracker Example {#mouse-tracker-example} 6039→ 6040→If we were to implement the mouse tracking functionality using the Composition API directly inside a component, it would look like this: 6041→ 6042→```vue [MouseComponent.vue] 6043→ 6057→ 6058→ 6059→``` 6060→ 6061→But what if we want to reuse the same logic in multiple components? We can extract the logic into an external file, as a composable function: 6062→ 6063→```js [mouse.js] 6064→import { ref, onMounted, onUnmounted } from 'vue' 6065→ 6066→// by convention, composable function names start with "use" 6067→export function useMouse() { 6068→ // state encapsulated and managed by the composable 6069→ const x = ref(0) 6070→ const y = ref(0) 6071→ 6072→ // a composable can update its managed state over time. 6073→ function update(event) { 6074→ x.value = event.pageX 6075→ y.value = event.pageY 6076→ } 6077→ 6078→ // a composable can also hook into its owner component's 6079→ // lifecycle to setup and teardown side effects. 6080→ onMounted(() => window.addEventListener('mousemove', update)) 6081→ onUnmounted(() => window.removeEventListener('mousemove', update)) 6082→ 6083→ // expose managed state as return value 6084→ return { x, y } 6085→} 6086→``` 6087→ 6088→And this is how it can be used in components: 6089→ 6090→```vue [MouseComponent.vue] 6091→ 6096→ 6097→ 6098→``` 6099→ 6100→
6101→ Mouse position is at: {{ x }}, {{ y }} 6102→
6103→ 6104→[Try it in the Playground](https://play.vuejs.org/#) 6105→ 6106→As we can see, the core logic remains identical - all we had to do was move it into an external function and return the state that should be exposed. Just like inside a component, you can use the full range of [Composition API functions](/api/#composition-api) in composables. The same `useMouse()` functionality can now be used in any component. 6107→ 6108→The cooler part about composables though, is that you can also nest them: one composable function can call one or more other composable functions. This enables us to compose complex logic using small, isolated units, similar to how we compose an entire application using components. In fact, this is why we decided to call the collection of APIs that make this pattern possible Composition API. 6109→ 6110→For example, we can extract the logic of adding and removing a DOM event listener into its own composable: 6111→ 6112→```js [event.js] 6113→import { onMounted, onUnmounted } from 'vue' 6114→ 6115→export function useEventListener(target, event, callback) { 6116→ // if you want, you can also make this 6117→ // support selector strings as target 6118→ onMounted(() => target.addEventListener(event, callback)) 6119→ onUnmounted(() => target.removeEventListener(event, callback)) 6120→} 6121→``` 6122→ 6123→And now our `useMouse()` composable can be simplified to: 6124→ 6125→```js{2,8-11} [mouse.js] 6126→import { ref } from 'vue' 6127→import { useEventListener } from './event' 6128→ 6129→export function useMouse() { 6130→ const x = ref(0) 6131→ const y = ref(0) 6132→ 6133→ useEventListener(window, 'mousemove', (event) => { 6134→ x.value = event.pageX 6135→ y.value = event.pageY 6136→ }) 6137→ 6138→ return { x, y } 6139→} 6140→``` 6141→ 6142→:::tip 6143→Each component instance calling `useMouse()` will create its own copies of `x` and `y` state so they won't interfere with one another.
